Active-site engineering of a frustrated-Lewis-pair Au-loaded Zn-Al catalyst for the highly stable synthesis of glycerol carbonate from co-utilisation of CO2 and glycerol Shizheng Zhang Writing – original draft Investigation a b Gongde Wu Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition a ⁎ Xiaoli Wang Writing – review & editing a Lin Deng Writing – review & editing Supervision b ⁎ Zhangjin Cao Writing – review & editing Investigation a b Jie Wan Software a Jin Zhang Software a Yanjun Liu Writing – review & editing a Jianfei Kan Writing – review & editing a Wei Xu Writing – review & editing a Lihua Hu Writing – review & editing a Congxiao Shang Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition c Zhengxiao Guo Writing – review & editing Supervision Funding acquisition c ⁎ a Energy Research Institute, Nanjing Institute of Technology, Nanjing 211167, China Energy Research Institute, Nanjing Institute of Technology Nanjing 211167 China Energy Research Institute, Nanjing Institute of Technology, Nanjing, 211167, China b Department of Municipal Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing 211189, China Department of Municipal Engineering, Southeast University Nanjing 211189 China Department of Municipal Engineering, Southeast University, Nanjing, 211189, China c HKU-CAS Joint Laboratory on New Materials and Department of Chemistry, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong Island, Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China HKU-CAS Joint Laboratory on New Materials and Department of Chemistry, The University of Hong Kong Hong Kong Island Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of China HKU-CAS Joint Laboratory on New Materials and Department of Chemistry, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong Island, Hong Kong SAR, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Solid frustrated-Lewis-pair catalysts, based on Zn-Al composite oxide modified loaded with Au (Aux/ZnAl-CHT), were prepared by calcination of hydrotalcite precursors and tested for the direct synthesis of glycerol carbonate using CO2 as the carbon source. An Au5/ZnAl-CHT catalyst shows the highest catalytic performance with the glycerol carbonate yield of 19.5 % and the selectivity of 50.5 % at 170 °C and 4.0 MPa CO2, while maintaining good thermal stability and excellent regeneration ability. A series of characterization results and density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated the introduction of Au leads to more frustrated-Lewis-pairs in Zn-Al composite oxide (ZnAl-CHT), which improve the adsorption and activation of CO2. Meanwhile, FTIR analysis indicates that glycerol is activated by Zn2+ for the formation of zinc glycerolate intermediates. The above dual synergistic activation processes effectively enhance the catalytic performance. And the reaction pathway is proposed for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from CO2 and glycerol. Graphical Abstract The dual synergistic activation of CO2 and glycerol on the surface of Au5/ZnAl-CHT effectively enhance the catalytic performance. Keywords Carbon dioxide FLPs Hydrotalcite Glycerol Glycerol Carbonate Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Stringent targets for net-zero carbon (CO2) emissions have been set by many countries and regions to combat climate change. While incorporation of renewable energy is a must, CO2 capture and utilization (CCU) plays a significant role in reducing excessive CO2 emissions, due to the current dominancy of fossil fuel energy consumptions [1]. Particularly conversion of CO2 into high-value added “green” chemicals can incentivize the rapid implementation of carbon capture technologies, of great significance in “hard-to-decarbonise” sectors, such as cement and steel manufacturing, and in resource-limiting countries/regions, where fossil fuel consumption is still a necessity [2,3]. Moreover, fossil fuel consumption, e.g. in oil refining, also generates a large surplus quantity of glycerol as a waste, which has been a persistent issue for the fuel-refining industry. Thus, efficient utilization of glycerol is also of great significance, especially in converting glycerol to high value-added products, such as 1,2-propanediol, acrolein and glycerol carbonate (GC) [4–6]. Particularly, GC is widely used as a high boiling point solvent and a cosmetic wetting agent, and is a prominent monomer for new functionalized polymers, due to its characteristics of nonflammability, low toxicity, low viscosity and low volatility [7–9]. Currently, synthesis methods of GC use different carbon source such as phosgene [10–12], urea [13–15], dimethyl carbonate [16–18], and carbon dioxide [19,20]. However, the phosgene method has been terminated owing to phosgene’s harmful consequences on environment and physical health [21]. The urea method often produces pungent odor of ammonia in the synthesis of GC [22]. In addition, dimethyl carbonate as a relatively expensive chemical is also uneconomical to scale up [23]. In contrast, direct synthesis of GC using both glycerol and CO2 wastes as raw materials holds epochal significance, as it not only transforms the greenhouse gas CO2 into high value-added chemicals, but also alleviates the serious surplus waste issue of the biodiesel byproduct, glycerol [24], effectively contributing to energy decarbonization and resourcification for secure and sustainable development. However, the direct synthesis of GC is usually limited by the high thermodynamic stability of CO2 and unsatisfactory catalytic performance, with low conversion, low yield and low selectivity. Therefore, developing an effective catalyst to efficiently activate CO2 and improve yield of GC is highly desirable. So far, a diverse range of catalysts have been investigated such as metal-modified zeolites [25], ion-exchange resins [26], and composite metal oxides (Co3O4-ZnO) [27]. However, the yield of GC is still relatively low, typically about 5 %. In order to eschew the thermodynamic limitations, dehydrating agents are employed to shift the equilibrium conditions [28]. Su et al. report a yield of 11.4 % GC, without a metal catalyst, using 2-cyanopyridine as the dehydrating agent, which points to a novel way for CO2 activation [29]. Wang et al. used 2-cyanopyridine as a dehydrant and DMF as a solvent, GC yield can reach up to 17.5 % [30]. Hydrotalcite is a special two-dimensional layered anionic clay with many appealing characteristics, such as adjustable structural composition, memory effect and ordered structure. Hydrotalcite-like materials are gradually considered for the synthesis of GC. Moreover, the mixed metal oxides obtained by calcination of the hydrotalcite-like compounds show thermally stable homogeneous dispersion of M2+ and M3+ sites at the atomic level over a large specific surface area, which maximise the valence-coupling and synergetic effects among different elements [31]. More importantly, the intrinsic properties of the catalysts derived from hydrotalcite-like precursors can be tuned by controlling the cationic composition [32]. Therefore, hydrotalcite-like materials are preferred here for the synthesis of GC. Mg-Al hydrotalcites, with a large surface area and improved pore structure, have been noted to show a high selectivity toward GC from the conversion of glycerol and dimethyl carbonate [33]. Using a Zn/Al/La/Li multimetal composite oxide with a relatively large surface area, glycerol and CO2 are directly converted into GC, with a yield of up to 15.1 % [34]. Zn/Al/La/Cl mixed oxides catalysts from the calcination of re-constructed hydrotalcites result in the formation of relatively thin plates and high specific surface area, which improve the GC yield to 16 % [35]. However, despite the extensive efforts, it is still challenging to achieve a GC high-yield directly from glycerol and CO2. As CO2 is an inert gas, its chemical bond CO is highly stable, resulting in thermodynamic limitation for direct GC synthesis [28]. Therefore, the CO2 activation has become a fundamental issue. To further address the fundamental issue, we propose an innovative approach that effectively utilizes the concept of "frustrated-Lewis-pair" for catalyst design. Frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) are a type of chemical catalyst that was first proposed in 2006 and composed of a Lewis acid and a Lewis base that are sterically hindered, or "frustrated," in their attempts to react with each other [36–38]. Unlike traditional Lewis acid-base reactions, FLPs do not form a stable adduct but instead undergo a reversible reaction that generates a reactive intermediate capable of activating small molecules such as H2, CO2 and N2. FLPs have shown great promise in catalyzing a wide range of organic transformations [39,40]. A previous report has identified that Au can avoid tight adsorption between Lewis acid and Lewis base, and serve as a coupling agent to join Lewis acid and Lewis base to construct an effective frustrated Lewis pair via the repulsion from the filled valence electrons of Au [41]. However, there is little attempt in the literature to use appropriate frustrated-Lewis-pair catalysts for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from glycerol and CO2. Thus, we aim to explore the potential of frustrated-Lewis-pair catalysts for this reaction and develop an innovative strategy to enhance their catalytic performance. Here, we designed the FLPs catalyst of Au-loaded ZnAl mixed oxides (Aux/ZnAl-CHT), derived from calcination of hydrotalcite precursors, which employed lattice O2− as the Lewis basic center, Al3+ and Zn2+, as the Lewis acidic center, Au as the potential “bridge” to joint Lewis acid and Lewis base and induce the FLPs formation. They were tested for the direct synthesis of GC from glycerol and CO2 in the presence of CH3CN as the dehydrating agent. The FLPs catalytic activity of ZnAl-CHT catalysts with a series of Au-loaded were investigated firstly by artificial poisoning experiment of the active site. The underlying structure-activity relationships were detailed unraveled via DFT calculations and analytical techniques, such as FTIR，XRD, XPS, BET, NH3/CO2-TPD and TG-DTG. Eventually, the result revealed that the potential FLPs developed on Au5/ZnAl-CHT resulted in superior catalytic performance, leading to a GC yield of 19.5 % and selectivity of 50.5 %. The possible mechanism of dual synergistic activation was thus proposed for the synthesis of GC over Au5/ZnAl-CHT. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Zn-Al composite oxide was prepared from the precursor of hydrotalcite by a coprecipitation method. Typically, at first 6.54 g ZnCl2, and 2.89 g AlCl3·6H2O were dissolved into 60 mL deionized water with M = 1; This mixed metal solution was added to 60 mL Na2CO3 solution in 0.05 mol/L concentration, and this mixture was kept in a NaOH solution at pH=10 under constant stirring. After the coprecipitation was completed, the obtained slurry was transferred into a magnetic stirrer and stirred at 60 °C for aging overnight. The aged sample was filtered with Brinell funnel and washed with deionized water for 4–5 times to ensure that the filtered cake was neutral. The filtered cake was put into an oven and dried at 80 °C for 15 h. The obtained solids were then calcined at 450 °C for 15 h, with an initial heating rate of a 5 °C/min. The resulting sample is denoted as ZnAl-CHT. Aux/ZnAl-CHT were prepared by loading Au over the ZnAl-CHT using chloroauric acid as the Au precursor. Briefly, 2 g prepared ZnAl-CHT were added into x mL of an aqueous solution of HAuCl4·4 H2O with 4.85×10−5 mol/mL and were stirred in a magnetic stirrer under room temperature overnight, and then was subsequently followed by filtration with Brinell funnel, The filtrated cake was dried overnight, and obtained solid was calcined at 450 °C for 15 h with an initial heating rate of a 5 °C/min. Eventually, the obtained catalysts are denoted as Aux/ZnAl-CHT, where x is the mL of HAuCl4·4 H2O, CHT stands for the calcinated hydrotalcite. Pristine ZnO was prepared by a similar precipitation method. 2.2 Characterizations of catalysts The crystallin structures of the prepared catalysts were characterized via X-ray diffraction (XRD) on a Rigaku Smartlab X-Ray Diffractometer with Cu radiation over a range of 5° to 90°. The local structure of the prepared catalysts was characterized via Fourier Transform Infrared spectra (FT-IR) on a Bruker Tensor-27 Infrared Spectrometer by the KBr disk method over a range of 400–4000 cm−1 with a 4 cm−1 resolution. The surface area of the prepared catalysts was evaluated by N2 adsorption-desorption on a Kubo-x-1000 Specific Surface Area and Pore Size Analyzer (Beijing Biot company). Before analysis, the catalyst was evacuated at 300 °C for 2 h to remove the water adsorbed in the catalyst and avoid affecting the analysis results. The surface basicity of the prepared catalysts was measured by temperature programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) on a Finesorb-3010 Chemisorption Instrument (FINETEC company). For the pretreatment, each sample (0.1 g，40–60 mesh) was pre-tread in Ar atmosphere at 300 °C. For the adsorption, the samples were purged with CO2 at 40 °C and subsequently purged with Ar to remove the physisorption of CO2. Desorption was programmed at a heating rate of 10 °C per min from 40 °C to 800 °C. The surface acidity was measured in a similar process but NH3 was introduced instead of CO2. Thermal stability was measured by thermogravimetric analysis (TG) using a Q600SDT thermal differential analyzer (TA Company). Each sample were recorded from 20 to 800 °C in a 10 °C/min heating rate under N2 atmosphere. Element composition and molecular structure of the prepared samples were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on a PHI5000 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (Japan ULVAC-PHI Corporation) equipped with mono-chromated Al Kα radiation. The binding energies were calibrated according to the C 1 s peak (284.8 eV) as internal labeling. The crystal morphology of catalysts was characterized by Japanese JEOL JEM-2100 F high-resolution field emission transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) equipped with an X-MaxN 80 T IE250 X-ray energy spectrometer. The elemental composition and distribution of the catalysts were also characterized by matching energy spectrometer (EDS). To obtain accurate measurements of each metal element in the prepared catalyst, elemental chemical analysis was performed using the inductively coupled plasma-optical (ICP) emission spectroscopy (PerkinElmer ICP OPTIMA–4300). 2.3 Calculation details Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were performed using the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) version 5.4.4. Exchange and correlation were treated within the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [42–45]. The energy convergence was set to 1.0 × 10−5 eV for the electronic loop. The plane wave basis set kinetic energy cutoff is 400 eV. A force threshold of 0.01 eV/Å is used for the optimization. All the calculations are carried out in the reciprocal space. A Fermi-level smearing with a Gaussian width of 0.1 eV was applied. For bulk wurtzite ZnO, we obtain optimized lattice parameters of 3.259 and 5.259 Å, which are comparable with the experimental values (3.250 and 5.207 Å) [46]. The ZnO(101̅0) surface was generated from the bulk with the 3×1×1 supercell. The Zn6Al2O9 (ZnAl-CHT) was built by dopping two Al to replace two Zn and creating another Zn vacancy. A 20 Å vacuum were included to avoid spurious periodic interactions. All three layers are allowed to relaxed. A 5×7×1 Monkhorst-Pack special k-points mesh is used to sum all the Brillouin zones. All calculations were carried out with spin polarization and dipole correction. To better describe the VdW interactions, DFT-D3 method of Grimme was applied [47]. 2.4 Catalyst test The typical testing procedures involved, the addition of 0.12 g catalyst, 2.3 g high-purity glycerol, relatively stable 5 mL acetonitrile (CH3CN) as dehydrating agent [48], and diethylene glycol monomethyl ether (DME) as an external standard for calibration, to a dry 25 mL autoclave. Then the autoclave was filled with 4.0 MPa CO2. After the full dissolution of CO2, the reactor was heated to 170 °C within 1 h, and then kept for 12 h under vigorous stirring. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled down to room temperature. The reacted liquid in the autoclave was analyzed using an Agilent 7890 A gas chromatography. And considering the relatively low solubility of glycerol and products in acetonitrile and high solubility in ethanol, ethanol was also added to dilute the reaction mixture. Conversion of glycerol (GL), selectivity of GC and yield of GC were calculated by the following equations. Conversion % = M GL i − M GL f M GL i × 100 Yield % = M GC M GL i × 100 Selectivity % = M GC M GL i − M GL f × 100 where M GL i is the initial molar quantity of glycerol before reaction; M GL f is the molar quantity of residual glycerol after reaction; M Gc is the molar quantity of GC product. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural and structural properties The physical and structural properties of the catalysts were investigated by XRD and N2 adsorption/desorption. As noted in Fig. 1, the XRD patterns of prepared ZnO catalyst showed a typical hexagonal structure. Due to high atomic ratio of Zn2+/Al3+ anions, ZnO diffraction peaks also exist in the Au-loaded catalysts. Peak intensity decreased and broadened evidently when Au was introduced, indicating a reduced degree of crystallinity and the formation of small crystal size. There are no diffraction peaks of Al2O3, indicating that Al2O3 probably existed in an amorphous state, and Zn6Al2O9 became the main phase in ZnAl-CHT catalyst when Al was introduced. Peaks ascribed to cubic Au phase (indicated by open triangle symbols) exist in the Aux/ZnAl-CHT, suggesting Au nanoparticles were loaded onto ZnAl-CHT catalysts successfully. The crystal morphology of ZnAl-CHT and Au5/ZnAl-CHT was determined by HRTEM, as shown in Fig. 2. It can be seen that the ZnAl-CHT mainly has a thin-plates morphology, with irregular sized particles agglomerated on the surface. Compared to Figs. 2a and 2b, the basic morphology of Au5/ZnAl-CHT changed slightly. After Au loading, although the crystal still appears as a thin plate, clusters of Au nanoparticles appear on the surface and the structure becomes disordered. And Au and ZnO lattice fringe of d-spacing was 0.23 nm and 0.28 nm, respectively, which was well corresponded to their (111) and (100) plane. The elemental composition and distribution of Au5/ZnAl-CHT and ZnAl-CHT were detected by EDS spectroscopy, as shown in Fig. 3. For the ZnAl-CHT in Fig. 3a, the Zn content on the surface of the ZnAl-CHT is 2–3 times of the Al content. Fig. 3b shows the distribution of metal elements in the Au5/ZnAl CHT. It demonstrated that Au nanoparticles are uniformly dispersing on the catalyst surface, indicating that Au has been successfully loaded onto ZnAl-CHT. This result is also consistent with the XRD results. In continuation of the EDS analysis, the accurate value of each metal element for ZnAl-CHT and Aux/ZnAl-CHT was determined by ICP as shown in Table 1. It was found that the element content on ZnAl support is generally consistent with EDS result and a small amount of Au was loaded onto ZnAl-CHT. The physical properties of surface area of the prepared catalyst were also summarized in Table 1. The pristine ZnO is characterized by a relatively low BET surface area compared with the other catalysts. When Al was introduced, specific area increased remarkably, which is attribute to the ionic radius of Al is smaller than that of Zn, leading to the increase of ZnAl-CHT disorder structure. So Al2O3 in the catalyst will be beneficial for increasing the catalyst specific area [49]. As expected, ZnAl-CHT and Aux/ZnAl-CHT both had higher specific area. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm plots of prepared catalysts were recorded and shown in Fig. 4. All prepared catalysts exhibit similar isotherms of a type IV characteristics, by IUPAC classification, with a H3 hysteresis loop, indicating the existence of a mesoporous structure in the prepared catalysts. The elemental chemical valence state of Au5/ZnAl-CHT and ZnAl-CHT catalysts were characterized by XPS as shown in Fig. 5. The data of the binding energies and surface composition was recorded in Table 2. The full XPS spectra, Fig. 5a, reveal four main elements in the catalysts. The high-resolution spectra of O1 s, Zn2p, Al2p, and Au4 f are shown in Fig. 5b-e respectively. For ZnAl-CHT, two peaks at 1020.97 and 1044.07 eV were ascribed to Zn2p3/2 and Zn2p1/2. However, the peak of Zn2p shifted to higher energies when Au was loaded, the phenomenon can be ascribed to the Au high electronegativity, which may result in partial electron transfer from Zn to Au, similar to that reported previously [35,41]. A higher binding energy of Zn 2p3/2 is conducive to the activation of glycerol [48]. The binding energy of Al 2p is marginally affected in ZnAl-CHT when Au was introduced. Fig. 5b shows the O1s spectra over ZnAl-CHT and Au5/ZnAl-CHT. The peak can be deconvoluted into three peaks, which was assigned to surface lattice oxygen Qα (around 530 eV), chemical adsorbed oxygen Qβ (around 531 eV), and hydroxyl and carbonate species Qγ (around 532 eV), respectively [50]. All surface oxygen species was calculated. Qβ is related to the existence of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [51]. Lattice oxygen is associated with the Lewis basic site. The Qα/Oβ ratio of ZnAl-CHT and Au5/ZnAl-CHT were 0.9 and 1.22 respectively. Therefore, compared with ZnAl-CHT, the level of Qα increased evidently for Au5/ZnAl-CHT. Thus, the observation suggests that more Lewis basic sites are formed over the Au5/ZnAl-CHT. The introduction of Au may be conducive to the transformation of adsorbed oxygen into lattice oxygen via the oxygen vacancies. NH3-TPD was preformed to analyze the acid sites of prepared catalyst as shown in Fig. 6a, and the property of acidity was summarized in Table 3. The peaks of the NH3-TPD profiles mainly exist around 450 °C. ZnO mainly shows a peak around 408 °C, indicating a moderate acidic site. However, when Al was introduced, the peak slightly shifted to higher temperature region around 450 °C, and total amount of the acidic sites increased significantly, which is related to the well-known acid center Al3+ of Al2O3 formed on the catalyst [52,53] and the acid sites of Zn-Al-O support [54,55]. ZnAl-CHT and Aux/ZnAl-CHT both show similarly strong peaks around 450 °C but differed in amount. The total acidic sites first increased from 3.31 to 5.03 a.u./g and then decreased from 5.03 to 3.08 a.u./g with the further loading of Au. It can be found that a certain amount of Au loading increased acidity of the catalyst, which may be related to the higher electronegativity of Au, and leads to a tendency for electrons to move towards Au, thereby enhancing the acidity of the metal ions [41]. Regarding CO2 as the feedstock of carbon source for direct GC synthesis, the study of CO2 adsorption-desorption is necessary for the interpretation of the properties of the basic sites. Therefore, CO2-TPD are performed and the profiles are shown in Fig. 6b. The basicity of the prepared catalyst is also summarized in Table 3. The CO2-TPD profiles can be divided into two regions (below and above 450 °C). It is easy to observe that ZnO shows a high-intensity desorption peak at 519 °C in the high temperature region, suggesting a strong basic site presented on the surface of ZnO, which could be mainly generated by lattice oxygen. When Al was introduced, it is interesting that CO2 desorption peak shift to low temperature region obviously and the CO2 desorption peak at 519 °C decrease sharply. This significantly indicates that lattice oxygen forms a new active site with the acidic Al3+. Previous paper report that appropriate Lewis acidic and basic sites cooperate to form frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs) due to the space frustration, which effectively and cooperatively activate a variety of small molecules (CO2, H2, NO) [37,40,56,57]. For the prepared ZnAl-CHT, the space frustration will cause the Lewis acid-base sites in the small space to be unable to bond effectively, thus facilitating the formation of solid FLPs [58,59]. In this case, CO2 can be adsorbed and activated due to potential FLPs active sites as well. Compared with the ZnAl-CHT, Aux/ZnAl-CHT exhibits a higher CO2 desorption which slightly shift to the low temperature region. The observation suggests that Au loading likely changed the binding of the chemisorbed CO2 on the active sites over ZnAl-CHT. Firstly, the interaction between Au and ZnAl oxide accelerated the transformation of chemisorption oxygen into surface lattice oxygen, and oxygen vacancies were converted to lattice oxygen [60], and then further caused an increased probability of FLPs formation, which is consistent with the XPS results. Secondly, the electronegative Au will cause Al3+(or Zn2+) to exhibit a stronger Lewis acidity, further enhancing the likelihood of FLPs formation. Therefore, Au as the potential “bridge” to joint Lewis acid and Lewis base and induce the FLPs formation. In addition, as can be seen from the overall Fig. 6b, the desorption peak of CO2 on Au5/ZnAl-CHT shifts to the lower temperature region at 426 °C. This indicates that the CO2 adsorbed on the FLPs of Au5/ZnAl-CHT is more active and likely shows superior reactivity. Then Gaussian Model was used to perform peak fitting on CO2-TPD. The CO2 desorption above 450 °C is mainly generated by lattice oxygen, while the desorption peaks below 450 °C are attributed to FLPs of Zn…O and Al…O that formed by Zn2+ and Al3+ together with lattice oxygen. The corresponding results are listed in Table 3. The influence of Au on the structure and Bader charge distribution of the catalyst was calculated by DFT. Figs. 7a and 7b shows the optimal structure and Bader charge distribution of ZnAl-CHT and Aux/ZnAl-CHT, respectively. The results indicated that the Bader charges of ZnAl-CHT were Zn1 (+1.2008e), Zn2 (+1.1360e), Zn3 (+1.1642e), O1 (-1.0959e) and O2 (-1.3563e). Zn3 and O2 are chemically bonded as Lewis acids and Lewis bases, respectively, which formed classical Lewis acid and base pairs instead of frustrated Lewis acid and base pairs. However, due to the spatial frustration, Zn2 and O2 cannot effectively combine together, thus forming a frustrated Lewis acid and base pair [58,59]. It is worth noting that when Au was loaded on ZnAl-CHT, the electronegativity of Au causes the Bader charge of Zn2 to rise to +1.1815e, which shows a stronger Lewis acidity. While the Bader charge of O2 drops to −1.3917e, which shows a stronger Lewis basicity. Therefore, Aux/ZnAl-CHT exhibits stronger FLPs characteristics compared with ZnAl-CHT. In addition, Figs. 7c and 7d indicates the distance between Zn2 and O2 decreases from 4.262 A to 4.187 A with the loading of Au, which further enhances the FLPs formation in Aux/ZnAl-CHT. It is well known that carbon dioxide is a nonpolar molecule, with the C atom having a small positive charge (δ+) and the O atom having a small negative charge (δ-). Therefore, O and C in CO2 will interact with the Zn2 Lewis acidic site and O2 Lewis basic site on Aux/ZnAl-CHT surface, respectively, and thus play an important role in activating CO2. At the same time, the loaded Au is also conducive to improving the adsorption performance of CO2 [61]. Therefore, Aux/ZnAl-CHT with strong FLP characteristics has both CO2 adsorption and activation functions, which provides a possibility for efficient chemical conversion of CO2 on its surface. 3.2 Catalytic activity studies Aiming to interpret the influence of Au loading on catalytic performance, a series of ZnAl-CHT with varying Au loading were tested under the condition of 170 °C and 4.0 MPa CO2. The catalytic performance of Aux/ZnAl-CHT, ZnAl-CHT and ZnO are shown in Table 4. Except for the GC main product, plenty of acetins were detected as the byproducts during the reaction e.g., monoacetin and diacetin. Both of them mainly derived from the reaction between glycerol and acetic acid [35,48]. A certain amount of hydrolysis of acetonitrile generated acetic acid and caused the side reaction. However, monoacetin finds applications in diverse industries, including the production of dynamite and the tanning of leather, and also serves as raw materials for food, soap, candle, viscose, etc. Diacetin can be used as a solvent for resin, camphor, and cellulose derivatives as well [62–64]. ZnO does not show much potential for the synthesis of GC from glycerol and CO2. Combined with the CO2-TPD profile, the low activity of ZnO can be explained by the high basic sites and low acid sites formed on catalyst. Firstly, the intermediate of the reaction was not easily desorbed from the active site in high basicity. Secondly, high basicity could lead to the decomposition of GC or decarbonylation to glycidol, resulting in the formation of byproduct, and moreover the decrease of yield and selectivity [65], this result is well in accordance with previous reports [65,66]. It also shows that the acidic site plays an important role in the reaction. Compared with ZnAl-CHT, a noticeable change was observed when Au was introduced, the yield and selectivity of GC reached the highest for Au5/ZnAl-CHT, the best yield of 19.5 % and selectivity of 50.5 % were obtained. However, when more Au was introduced, the catalytic performance began to drop sharply. It indicated that the amount of Au loading was important for improving the catalyst performance. Additionally, combined with CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD result, CO2 may be efficiently activated by FLPs formed from appropriate number of basic and acid sites over Aux/ZnAl-CHT and ZnAl-CHT, which has high density of basic and acid sites and provides more opportunities to generate FLPs comparing to ZnO (listed in Table 3). So Au5/ZnAl-CHT exhibited best catalytic performance, which was also associated with more FLPs developed on catalyst comparing to ZnAl-CHT. To further demonstrate the requirement of the coexistence of Lewis acidic and basic sites for the FLPs-like activity, the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from CO2 and glycerol was conducted in the presence of pyridine or pyrrole. The Lewis base pyridine was employed as a strong base molecule to absorb on the Lewis acidic sites of Au5/ZnAl-CHT and Lewis acid pyrrole was also employed as a acid molecule to absorb on the Lewis basic sites of Au5/ZnAl-CHT [67]. When they were added to the reaction respectively, the FLPs can be effectively blocked by the pyridine and pyrrole molecule. As shown in Fig. 8a, pyridine obviously terminated the synthesis of glycerol carbonate and the yield sharply declined. Similarly, as shown in Fig. 8b, the addition of 0.05 mol pyrrole also terminated the reaction with a yield of almost zero. Due to pyridine or pyrrole molecule blocking surface Lewis acidic or basic sites on Au5/ZnAl-CHT, the formation of FLPs was inhibited and the catalyst thus lost their FLPs-like activity, revealing the necessity of the coexistence of Lewis acidic and Lewis basic sites on the surface of Au5/ZnAl-CHT to activate CO2 and achieve high catalytic performance. Reaction temperature is an important factor determining the catalytic performance, therefore the thermal catalytic activity over Au5/ZnAl-CHT was examined through varying reaction temperature as shown in Fig. 9a. All reactions followed the same conditions except for the reaction temperature. The results suggest that the conversion increases gradually with increasing temperature over the whole temperature range. However, the yield and selectivity reach the highest consistently at 170 °C and an opposite trend is observed above 170 °C. The decline of selectivity may be related to the acetonitrile hydrolysis and the decomposition or transformation of GC. A higher temperature could accelerate the hydrolysis of acetonitrile and further to generate more acetic acid. Previous reports also reveal that a high temperature aggravates undesired reactions resulting in the formation of byproducts [34,68]. Therefore, the direct synthesis of GC from CO2 and glycerol is better conducted around 170 °C. CO2 pressure is another important parameter in the synthesis of GC and was also assessed here to determine the optimal condition. The results in Fig. 9b indicate that an improvement of yield from 9.5 % to 19.5 % is achieved between 2.5 and 4.0 MPa of CO2 pressure. However, no appreciable change was observed when CO2 pressure exceeds 4.0 MPa, the yield and selectivity remain nearly constant when CO2 pressure was surged to 5.0 MPa. Although a higher CO2 pressure favors catalytic performance, the improvement was limited. Hence, based on these data, it is suggested that the optimal condition of CO2 pressure was about 4.0 MPa. The impact of reaction time was depicted in Fig. 9c. Within the first 12 h, GC yield increased rapidly. However, after that, no noticeable change was obtained, indicating reaction neared thermodynamic equilibrium. Therefore, 12 h reaction time is optimal for the direct synthesis of GC in this catalytic system. The impact of the catalyst amount was depicted in Fig. 9d. With the increase of the catalyst loading from 0.04 g to 0.12 g, the GC yield and selectivity increased evidently and achieved the best catalytic performance at 0.12 g in this reactive system. When more catalyst was added into reaction, the GC yield and selectivity decreased, which can be attributed to acetonitrile hydrolysis with more catalyst, the hydrolysis of acetonitrile lead to more acetic acid production. Therefore, the optimal dose of catalyst should be controlled at 0.12 g. 3.3 Catalyst reusability and thermal stability studies Catalyst reusability experiment over Au5/ZnAl-CHT for the direct synthesis of GC from CO2 and glycerol was conducted at the condition of 170 °C, 4.0 MPa CO2, 12 h reaction, 0.12 g catalyst, and 5 mL CH3CN as a dehydrating agent. The experiment results are shown in Fig. 10. The GC yield of 19.5 % and the GC selectivity of 50.5 % were obtained over fresh catalyst. The spent catalyst was regenerated via calcination at 450 °C under N2 atmosphere for removing the products strongly adsorbed on active sites after reaction and retaining catalytic activity. For the first recycle of the regenerated catalyst, there was a slight drop in glycerol yield from 19.5 % to 18.1 %, which might have been caused by the deactivation of a few active sites that were unable to be restored during the calcination process. Until the third recycling, the activity was almost unchanged, indicating the structural integrity was not destroyed. Therefore, Au5/ZnAl-CHT had a strong regeneration ability. Table 5 shows the comparison of catalytic performance with previous literature under similar reaction condition. Other catalytic processes are not included in the statistics, such as electrocatalysis, fixed-bed catalysis, etc. Although the selectivity of Au5/ZnAl-CHT catalysts may not exhibit a significant advantage, it demonstrated a higher yield, a less dosage or excellent reusability compared to other catalysts, which may have development potential in industrial production of GC from GL and CO2. For investigating the thermal stability of prepared catalysts, Au5/ZnAl-CHT as a typical catalyst was characterized by TG-DTG, as shown in Fig. 11. the TG profile of Au5/ZnAl-CHT presented three major weight losses. The first weight loss around 42 °C was ascribed to elimination of water molecules weakly absorbed on catalysts [70]. The second weight loss around 169 °C was ascribed to the elimination of interlayer water molecules over Au5/ZnAl-CHT [71]. The third weight loss around 508 °C was ascribed to the decarbonation on impure catalyst [72]. The materials weight did not change significantly as the temperature rose, and weight loss inclined to be stable, suggesting that Au5/ZnAl-CHT had a good thermal stability. 3.4 Mechanism of the catalysis The FT-IR spectra of ZnO as reference sample and the FT-IR spectra of ZnAl oxide catalysts with varying Au loading after CO2 adsorption were shown in Fig. 12a. The infrared spectra among prepared Aux/ZnAl-CHT catalysts are very similar, and they all show a very broadband between 2700 and 3750 cm−1. Accordingly, the very broadband was a superimposed peak ascribed to partly CO3-H2O bridging mode, H-bonded interlayer H2O, and metal-OH-stretching mode, however it was difficult to distinguish the various metals bonded to OH group [73]. The wavenumber bands between 400 and 500 cm−1 could be attributed to lattice vibrations (Zn-O, Al-O). The appeared peak at 703 and 501 cm−1 were ascribed to the stretching modes of Al-O. From Fig. 12b, the band at 1383 and 1398 cm−1 was assigned to free carbonate species on the surface [74]. The band at 1618 and 1234 cm−1 are both ascribed to the bidentate carbonate [75], which is related to a C atom of CO2 bind to a Lewis basic lattice O2− and a O atom of CO2 bind to a Lewis acidic Al3+ [75–78]. For the five kinds of catalysts, ZnO lacks sufficient acidic sites, resulting in the indistinct characteristic peak of bidentate adsorption. Compared with ZnAl-CHT, a distinct bidentate adsorption peak can be observed on Au/ZnAl-CHT. This indicates that under the bridging effect of Au, the combination of acidic and basic sites forms frustrated Lewis pairs (FLPs). This result is consistent with the characterization results of CO2-TPD and DFT calculations, suggesting that the presence of more FLPs contributes to the activation of CO2. The fresh Au5/ZnAl-CHT and spent Au5/ZnAl-CHT were characterized by FT-IR to give an insight into the mechanism of the active species for the synthesis of GC from CO2 and glycerol as shown in Fig. 13. The spent Au5/ZnAl-CHT was also calcinated and characterized. The band at 1950 cm−1 was assigned to the O-H…O bending mode of zinc glycerolate formed from the reaction of glycerol and ZnO [79]. When zinc glycerolate formed, there were a new C-H stretching band appeared at 2845 cm−1 and new C-O stretching of glycerol appeared at 1062 cm−1 and 1126 cm−1. When spent Au5/ZnAl-CHT catalyst was calcinated, the band at 1950 cm−1 obviously disappeared, indicating the deposition of zinc glycerolate revert to the ZnO nanoparticles. The regenerated catalyst Au5/ZnAl-CHT showed similar FT-IR spectra with Au5/ZnAl-CHT, confirming that the catalyst can be easily recovered. The XRD characterization of the spent and re-calcinated Au5/ZnAl-CHT were shown in Fig. 14. It was found that there is a trace amount of impurity crystal phase produced, which may be attributed to the formation of trace amounts of zinc glycerolate [34]. However, the catalyst still maintains its original hexagonal structure, and the re-calcinated Au5/ZnAl-CHT also showed similar XRD pattern with fresh Au5/ZnAl-CHT. Based on the above results, the following mechanism was proposed for the synthesis of GC over Au5/ZnAl catalyst as shown in Fig. 15. In fact, the mechanism has been clearly proposed in many publications and most of the Zn-based catalysts show similar reaction routes [34,48,69]. For the mechanisms of CO2 activation, CO2 was activated by FLPs through the respective interactions between Lewis basic sites/C and Lewis acidic sites/one O atom of CO2, oxygens in CO2 in the form of a bridge bidentate carbonate. Zn2+ of Zn-O would activate glycerol and couple with activated CO2- to form zinc glycerolate, further forming cyclic metal carbonate as many reports suggest the generation of cyclic carbonate formed by intramolecular nucleophilic attack of alkoxy groups to carbonyl carbon atoms [80,81], and eventually producing GC through intramolecular rearrangement. The formed FLPs played a critical role in CO2 activation and further promoted efficiency. Based on this mechanism, Au participated in this reaction as a co-catalyst, activated the lattice oxygen more efficiently, and as a potential “bridge” encouraged the development and activity of FLPs. The above promotion effects over the Au5/ZnAl-CHT worked synergistically and result in boosted catalytic performance. 4 Conclusions An effective Aux/ZnAl-CHT catalyst has been developed by simple coprecipitation and tested for the direct synthesis of GC co-utilising CO2 and glycerol wastes. The optimized Au5/ZnAl-CHT catalyst shows excellent conversion of GC with a high yield of 19.5 % and the selectivity of 50.5 % at 170 °C and 4.0 MPa CO2. Moreover, Au5/ZnAl-CHT also exhibited high thermal stability and strong regeneration ability. It was identified that Au plays a significant role in efficiently activating the lattice oxygen and a potential “bridge” promoting the formation of frustrated Lewis pair. Moreover, the addition of Au favors the transformation of adsorbed oxygen into lattice oxygen via oxygen vacancies, and generated more FLPs active sites, thus boost CO2 adsorption and activation, synergistically leading to an enhanced catalytic performance. This study demonstrated the strong promotion effect of Au on ZnAl-CHT and offers an approach for co-resourcification of industrial wastes, CO2 and glycerol, into high value-added chemicals using FLPs as catalyst for sustainable development. coredata.dc:description: Solid frustrated-Lewis-pair catalysts, based on Zn-Al composite oxide modified loaded with Au (Aux/ZnAl-CHT), were prepared by calcination of hydrotalcite precursors and tested for the direct synthesis of glycerol carbonate using CO2 as the carbon source. An Au5/ZnAl-CHT catalyst shows the highest catalytic performance with the glycerol carbonate yield of 19.5 % and the selectivity of 50.5 % at 170 °C and 4.0 MPa CO2, while maintaining good thermal stability and excellent regeneration ability. A series of characterization results and density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicated the introduction of Au leads to more frustrated-Lewis-pairs in Zn-Al composite oxide (ZnAl-CHT), which improve the adsorption and activation of CO2. Meanwhile, FTIR analysis indicates that glycerol is activated by Zn2+ for the formation of zinc glycerolate intermediates. The above dual synergistic activation processes effectively enhance the catalytic performance. And the reaction pathway is proposed for the synthesis of glycerol carbonate from CO2 and glycerol.

coredata.dc:title: Active-site engineering of a frustrated-Lewis-pair Au-loaded Zn-Al catalyst for the highly stable synthesis of glycerol carbonate from co-utilisation of CO2 and glycerol
